catgry.labl: Veteran, on active duty in Reserves or National Guard only
Veteran, on active duty prior to past year
Veteran, on active duty in past year
Training for Reserves or National Guard only

var.name: VET1930
var.txt: VET1930 indicates whether the respondent was an ex-service veteran (Army, Navy, or Marine Corps) for any war or military expedition (Boxer Rebellion, Mexican Expedition, etc.). Those in the service during any period at which the U.S. was at war were considered veterans, as well as those who participated in a particular military expedition. Those in the service during peacetime were not to be considered veterans.

catgry.labl: Veteran status missing or not a veteran
Spanish-American, Philippine Insurrection or Boxer Rebellion
World War I and other war

var.name: VET1940
var.txt:
VET1940 indicates whether sample-line persons answered "yes" to the original 1940 veteran status question: "Is this person a veteran of the United States military forces; or the wife, widow, or under-18-year-old child of a veteran?"
The code "8" ("Not ascertained") includes those sample-line persons who left this question blank.
Past active service in the U.S. military forces (Army, Navy, or Marine Corps) by men, in times of war or peace, were included in this veteran definition. It did not include men who were on active duty at the time of enumeration or men who had performed all their military service in the National Guard, the Reserves (Army, Navy, or Marine), Reserve Officers' Training Corps, Citizens' Military Training Camp, or other branch not a part of the regular military establishment.

catgry.labl: Not veteran, spouse, or (under 18 years old) child of vetera
Veteran, spouse, or child of veteran

var.name: VETWWI
var.txt: VETWWI indicates whether persons were engaged in active-duty military service in the armed forces of the United States during the World War I era (between April 1917 and November 1918). It does not include persons currently in the armed forces or those who performed military service in the National Guard, the Reserves (Army, Navy, or Marine), Reserve Officers' Training Corps, Citizens Military Training Camp, Merchant Marine, or other branch not a part of the regular military establishment, unless the individual was called up for active duty. See VETSTAT, the screening variable for veterans variables, for more information on the types of service included in or excluded from the veterans variables.

var.name: VETPER
var.txt:
VETPER reports the period of military service for those individuals identified as code 2 in VET1940 (veterans and wives/widows/non-adult children of veterans).
Response categories are defined by the name of the military action (or a combination of actions), not by date (e.g., World War I, not 1917-1918).
VETPER does not include men (or the wives and children of such men) who were currently in the armed forces or who performed all their military service in the National Guard, the Reserves (Army, Navy, or Marine), Reserve Officers' Training Corps, Citizens Military Training Camp, Merchant Marine, or other branch not a part of the regular military establishment.
See VETSTAT, the screening variable for veterans variables, for more information on the types of service included in or excluded from the veterans variables.

catgry.labl: Spanish-Amer, Philippine Insurrection or Boxer Rebellion

var.name: VETCHILD
var.labl: Mortality status of child's veteran father
var.txt:
VETCHILD indicates whether a sample-line child's father was a veteran (living or dead). As with the other veteran variables, only past active duty in the main branches of the U.S. military (e.g., the Army, Navy, or Marines) counted toward veteran status. Service in the National Guard, the Reserves (Army, Navy, or Marine), Reserve Officers' Training Corps, Citizens Military Training Camp, Merchant Marine, or other branch not a part of the regular military establishment was not included, unless the father was called up for active duty. Fathers currently in the armed forces were not considered veterans.
See VETSTAT for more information on the types of service included or excluded from the veteran variables.

catgry.labl: Child not identified as having veteran father

var.name: HISTID
var.txt:
HISTID is a consistent individual-level identifier.
The variables SERIAL and PERNUM uniquely identify individuals within a dataset. However, the specific respondents associated with those unique values can change as historical full count datasets are improved. HISTID allows researchers to track specific individuals regardless of any such changes as it is a unique identifier independent of household and position within household. Researchers can then merge their existing data with newer versions of the data file using HISTID and identify updates, corrections, or improvements that may have been applied to the data.
var.codInstr: HISTID is a 36-character, consistent individual-level identifier.

var.name: IMGMISS
var.labl: Identifies person with missing data due to bad microfilm images
var.txt:
The preliminary version of the 1910 100% data file contains a small number of individuals with incompletely digitized variables due to unreadable microfilm images.
IMGMISS identifies individuals with systematically missing values for the following variables: YRSMARR LANGUAGE SPEAKENG CHBORN CHSURV CITIZEN OCC1950 IND1950 CLASSWKR EMPSTAT WKSUNEMP LIT SCHOOL OWNERSHP MORTGAGE FARM VETCIVWR BLIND DEAF
Note that OWNERSHP, MORTGAGE and FARM are household level variables; hence some person records identified by IMGMISS may have legitimate values for these household variables if household enumeration began on the previous page.

catgry.labl: Individual without missing data due to bad microfilm images
Individual with missing data due to bad microfilm images

var.name: SURSIM
var.txt: SURSIM assigns the same code to all persons within each household who had the same surname. Persons coded 1, including the household head, had the same surname as the household head. Other surnames are assigned codes in the order in which they appear within the household on the census form. Persons within a household who shared a surname will have the same code for this variable.

var.name: RELSTR
var.labl: Relationship to household head, alphabetic string
var.txt: RELSTR contains the original alphabetic string describing an individual's relationship to the head of household or householder. Beginning in 1880, data on household relationship was asked of every person. For a coded version of RELSTR see the variable RELATE.
var.codInstr:
RELSTR is a 50-character alphabetic string variable which describes an individual's relationship to the head of household or householder. Beginning in 1880, data on household relationship was asked of every person. For a numeric version of RELSTR see the variable RELATE. RELSTR specific variable codes for missing, edited, or unidentified observations, observations not applicable (N/A), observations not in universe (NIU), top and bottom value coding, etc. are provided below if applicable by Census year (and data sample if specified).
RELSTR Specific Variable Codes

var.name: BPLSTR
var.txt: BPLSTR is the original alphabetic string indicating the U.S. state, the outlying U.S. area or territory, or the foreign country where the person was born. It is used to construct the coded variable BPL.
var.codInstr:
BPLSTR is a 50-character alphabetic string variable which reports the U.S. state, outlying U.S. area or territory, or foreign country where the respondent was born. It is used to construct the numeric variable BPL. BPLSTR specific variable codes for missing, edited, or unidentified observations, observations not applicable (N/A), observations not in universe (NIU), top and bottom value coding, etc. are provided below if applicable by Census year (and data sample if specified).
BPLSTR Specific Variable Codes

var.name: MBPLSTR
var.txt: MBPLSTR contains the original alphabetic string of the U.S. state, the outlying U.S. area or territory, or the foreign country where the respondent's mother was born. MBPLSTR is used to construct the coded variable MBPL.
var.codInstr:
MBPLSTR is a 50-character alphabetic string variable which reports the U.S. state, outlying U.S. area or territory, or foreign country where the respondent's mother was born. It is used to construct the numeric variable MBPL. MBPLSTR specific variable codes for missing, edited, or unidentified observations, observations not applicable (N/A), observations not in universe (NIU), top and bottom value coding, etc. are provided below if applicable by Census year (and data sample if specified).
MBPLSTR Specific Variable Codes

var.name: FBPLSTR
var.txt: FBPLSTR contains the original alphabetic string of the U.S. state, the outlying U.S. area or territory, or the foreign country where the respondent's father was born. FBPLSTR is used to construct the coded variable FBPL.
var.codInstr:
FBPLSTR is a 50-character alphabetic string variable which reports the U.S. state, outlying U.S. area or territory, or foreign country where the respondent's father was born. It is used to construct the numeric variable FBPL. FBPLSTR specific variable codes for missing, edited, or unidentified observations, observations not applicable (N/A), observations not in universe (NIU), top and bottom value coding, etc. are provided below if applicable by Census year (and data sample if specified).
FBPLSTR Specific Variable Codes

var.name: OCCSTR
var.txt: OCCSTR contains the original unedited occupational entry from the census manuscript. Most users will prefer to use OCC1950 or OCC, which code the original occupational entries into coherent categories.
var.codInstr:
OCCSTR is a 52-character alphabetic string variable which reports the respondent's original unedited occupational response. It is used to construct the numeric variable OCC. OCCSTR specific variable codes for missing, edited, or unidentified observations, observations not applicable (N/A), observations not in universe (NIU), top and bottom value coding, etc. are provided below if applicable by Census year (and data sample if specified).
OCCSTR Specific Variable Codes

var.name: PERNUM80
var.labl: Person number, before large group quarters were split up, 1880 100%
var.txt:
PERNUM80 provides the original person number in the 1880 100% dataset.
As a part of IPUMS data processing, group quarters units containing more than 60 people were split into 1-person households, each with their own unique value in the IPUMS SERIAL variable. For this reason, the SERIAL variable makes it impossible to identify any group of people who share a group quarters unit containing more than 60 people.
Persons in each of these new 1-person households were assigned a PERNUM value of 1, regardless of their location in the original group quarters unit. Researchers needing to analyze intact group quarters units containing more than 60 people (such as the residents of a large prison or poorhouse) should use SERIAL80 and PERNUM80, instead of SERIAL and PERNUM.
SERIAL80 assigns a common serial number to all residents of each group quarters and housing unit, regardless of size. PERNUM80 identifies the order that each person was listed by enumerators in all housing units and group quarters of all sizes.
Whereas PERNUM ranges from 1 to 60, PERNUM80 ranges from 1 to 2990, since the largest group quarters unit in the 1880 100% dataset contains 2990 people.
Units that were split into 1-person households can be identified with the SPLIT80 variable.
var.codInstr:
PERNUM80 is a 4-digit numeric variable which numbers all persons within each household consecutively in the order in which they appear in the original 1880 100% dataset. As a part of IPUMS data processing, group quarters units containing more than 60 people were split into 1-person households, each with their own unique value in the IPUMS SERIAL variable. Hence, while PERNUM ranges from 1 to 60, PERNUM80 ranges from 1 to 2990, since the largest group quarters unit in the 1880 100% dataset contains 2990 people. PERNUM80 specific variable codes for missing, edited, or unidentified observations, observations not applicable (N/A), observations not in universe (NIU), top and bottom value coding, etc. are provided below if applicable by Census year (and data sample if specified).
PERNUM80 Specific Variable Codes

var.name: PAUPER
var.txt: PAUPER identifies persons classified as "paupers," the contemporary term for persons dependent upon charity or local welfare, such as an almshouse. The 1860 instructions to enumerators defined a pauper as a person who, at the time of enumeration or during the past year, was "so indigent or destitute of the means of support as to require the support of the community, obtained either by alms-begging or public maintenance, by taxation or poor fund." The rarity of affirmative responses indicates that pauperism was underreported.

var.name: CRIME
var.txt: CRIME indicates: 1) persons who had been convicted of a crime in the previous year, even if they were not in jail, and 2) incarcerated criminals. The nature of the person's offense is noted. The instructions to enumerators urged reliance on county records and the enumerator's "own knowledge" to identify non-institutionalized criminals, since questioning families directly "might give offense."

var.name: VOTE
var.txt: VOTE indicates whether persons were denied the right to vote on grounds other than rebellion (i.e., participating in the Confederacy during the Civil War) or other crimes. This question was intended to measure whether male citizens were denied suffrage on the basis of "race, color, or previous condition of servitude"-exclusions nominally made illegal by the Fifteenth Amendment.

catgry.labl: Yes, denied the right to vote

var.name: SSENROLL
var.txt: SSENROLL indicates whether the respondent had ever received a Social Security number, signifying enrollment in the Social Security program.
